Feeling + sweet and salty. There is no sign at the entrance on the first floor, so you have to ask the staff. Do not take the hotel elevator. Parking is only valet, and if you get validation, it costs $16.50 for 2 hours and 30 minutes. Wagyu BBQ is better than seafood. King crab. Lobster, sashimi. $109 (Friday, Saturday, Sunday). Make a reservation 2 months in advance. If you don't want to wait, you can eat at the bar for $139. For $109, I grill the meat. For $139, the staff grills it and brings it to you. Japanese A5 top sirloin flower. chelf choice A5. It's delicious, but it's too oily to eat a lot, so it's a shame. I thought From Chef would be special, so I ordered a few, but except for the lobster tail, there's nothing that's "wow~ delicious", and I'm so full that it's hard to eat anything else, so I don't recommend it. I think it felt even more greasy because there were no vegetables or refreshing flavors to go with the grill. I saw oysters and scrubs on YouTube, but they weren't there the day I went. The lobster was hard to eat because the shell didn't separate because they cooked it somehow. The king crab wasn't high quality, but it was all small and low quality and not very edible, so it was a bit disappointing. You have to call 24 hours in advance for dry-aged meat. The atmosphere is good, but the servers are busy and they bring it a bit late when you order. It's a bit disappointing because there's nothing worth eating for the price. I don't think I'll come back again because the price is too high. Food: 3 Service: 3 Atmosphere: 5

Dined at this place, and the disappointments just keep rearing its ugly head. The reservation and the menu are misleading at best, downright scammy at worst.

Welcome to bait and switch at its finest.

First of all, nowhere in the reservation process tells you that if you reserve $139/$149, you will NOT have a grill. So that's the biggest surprise. When asked, the server was trained to ask back, "Did you reserve a grill?" Knowing in the reservation process, there was no indication of reserving a grill or table service. You would think that important detail should be indicated.
Not sure why their reservation system was set up this way, regardless if it's the poor planning and designing or if it's intentionally done, we felt tricked.

Second, the menu you see on their official website is a joke. You'd think the menu online is updated and is what you'll get and is what you used to decide if you'll dine here, Surprise! Most of the items we wanted are not on the "restaurant menu". For example, Oysters, grilled or raw, were nowhere to be found, and there were absolutely no scallops. The ultimate sashimi platter disappeared from the menu as well. And guess what, all the waygu meats that you see on the menu and it's at the buffet station that you thought was unlimited? Yeah, NOPE, you can't grab them because you ain't got a grill üòÇ. Jokes on you. You have to order them, and they take 30+ minutes to arrive at your table cold with no flavor. Just imagine undercooked fatty meat cold and bland in your mouth. ü§Æ

Finally, the food. Like I mentioned, the sliced waygu meats were gross. They were undercooked, cold, and tasteless. The Tomahawk Steak was good. It needed more black pepper and salt but was cooked perfectly. Handful selections of raw food at the buffet station were good. It's probably the only thing I enjoyed. Lobster tails were ok, but the crab legs sucked. The small dishes "from chef" sucked real bad. The dessert was disgusting.

NO, it's definitely not worth the price.

I wondered how I got this experience when I thought I did my research... so I skimmed through the reviews and realized almost all good reviews are made by accounts that have a total of 1 review ü§î. üôÑ Service Dine in Meal type Dinner Price per person $100+ Food: 1 Service: 2 Atmosphere: 2

Not sure why their reservation system was set up this way, regardless if it's the poor planning and designing or if it's intentionally done, we felt tricked.

Second, the menu you see on their official website is a joke. You'd think the menu online is updated and is what you'll get and is what you used to decide if you'll dine here, Surprise! Most of the items we wanted are not on the "restaurant menu". For example, Oysters, grilled or raw, were nowhere to be found, and there were absolutely no scallops. The ultimate sashimi platter disappeared from the menu as well. And guess what, all the waygu meats that you see on the menu and it's at the buffet station that you thought was unlimited? Yeah, NOPE, you can't grab them because you ain't got a grill üòÇ. Jokes on you. You have to order them, and they take 30+ minutes to arrive at your table cold with no flavor. Just imagine undercooked fatty meat cold and bland in your mouth. ü§Æ

Finally, the food. Like I mentioned, the sliced waygu meats were gross. They were undercooked, cold, and tasteless. The Tomahawk Steak was good. It needed more black pepper and salt but was cooked perfectly. Handful selections of raw food at the buffet station were good. It's probably the only thing I enjoyed. Lobster tails were ok, but the crab legs sucked. The small dishes "from chef" sucked real bad. The dessert was disgusting.

NO, it's definitely not worth the price.

Having eaten at the Chubby Cattle BBQ, Mikiya, and Wagyu House by the X Pot, I'm a fan of the Chubby Cattle Restaurant Group so this review is tough for me to write because my expectations were high, especially given how difficult it was to secure a reservation here and the $149/person price point.

Long story short: This place is good as a one-time experience. Raw bar was only OK,--everything is salty except the sashimi and lobster, you do not get to cook your own meat (which means you will not be able to control the tempo / pace at which you eat or eat it "fresh" off the grill), A5 Wagyu ribeye, top blade, and tomahawk are OK, but nothing stands out especially given the $149 price point.  The one area I'd like to highlight is the amazing service. The whole staff is friendly, fast, helpful and warm!

The details:

The raw bar was just OK, the California King Crab (which looks like a mini version of the Alaska King crab) was very salty, the sashimi and lobster tails were solid, and the remaining items such as the fried chicken, salad, were OK but not what you're paying $149 for.  At the $149 price point, you will not get to cook your own meat which means that the food may come out lukewarm (like it did for us). The Tomahawk, A5 ribeye, A5 top blade were good but nothing that would make me want to come back again for. The A5 round top was very dry and I do not recommend ever ordering this. The small plates that are a must-try include the miso Chilean Sea Bass, oxtail potstickers, and katsu sando. Food: 2 Service: 5 Atmosphere: 5

Food: 2
Service: 5
Atmosphere: 5

**Disappointing Experience at Niku X**

We had high hopes for our visit to Niku X, but unfortunately, the experience fell far short of expectations. As a group of eight, we booked the full-service option and arrived at 8:30 PM for our 8:45 reservation. Despite arriving early, we weren‚Äôt seated until 9 PM, which was frustrating and set the tone for the evening.

Once seated, things only got worse. The grill at our table was broken, and we were told there was no other table available to accommodate us. Since we paid for the full-service option, we weren‚Äôt even allowed to grill our own meat, which we would have preferred given the circumstances.

The service was painfully slow. It took over an hour for the first round of our limited 15 items to arrive, leaving us with little time to enjoy the meal within the 2-hour limit. The presentation of the meat was subpar‚Äîcuts were not well-prepared or what you'd expect from a high-end restaurant.

The most disappointing part was the quality of the food. The A5 wagyu beef from our second order was chewy and lacked the signature tenderness you‚Äôd expect from wagyu. It was so poor that we questioned whether it was even wagyu at all.

While some staff members were polite, the overall experience was not worth the $1,500 we paid. Waiting for food, dealing with a broken grill, and being unable to enjoy the meal as promised made for a truly disappointing evening. We won‚Äôt be returning and can‚Äôt recommend this restaurant. I hate being a party pooper, especially when I am a huge fan of Chubby group restaurants like Mikiya and X Pot. But tonight, we were completely underwhelmed by Niku X. This restaurant  most definitely underdelivered for the $139 that they were charging. As a family, we eat fresh seafood regularly. So, we know what freshness tastes like. Perhaps it was the Thanksgiving long weekend and their suppliers had hard time delivering fresh seafood, or perhaps the restaurant's latest delivery was the day before Thanksgiving, when we visited the restaurant on Saturday, the seafood simply tasted unfresh. Many fish dishes had a mushy/slimy texture to them, and the shrimps/lobsters tasted unusually plain. The A5 Wagyu beef was tender, but they were all served on a large cold plate. By the time they were delivered to our table, the Wagyu pieces were all lukewarm. And eating beef with high fat content at a lukewarm temperature was definitely not an enjoyment, and even the Wagyu fried rice was lukewarm when served. The manager did come out and apologize, which was a nice gesture. I might try this restaurant again in the future, but will definitely avoid long weekend at all cost. BTW, I tried to scan the receipt using their Chubby app to accumulate points in the parking garage, but the app said it could only scan while we were physically inside the restaurant. So, for those of you who wish to use their app to accumulate points, please make sure to do so before you leave their premises.

Update: I had to down grade their food from 2 stars to 1 because both my older son and I had a miserable night last night after we came home. Food: 1 Service: 4 Atmosphere: 4

Niku restaurant is a bit of a letdown. The vibe is nice with modern decor, but it‚Äôs way too dim for my taste. Our server, Mike, was friendly and helpful. However, the buffet bar was way too dark, especially the sushi section. The lobster was tiny, like the ones you'd find at a Chinese buffet, and it was dry. The King crab was way too salty, had to drink water just to get it down. The made-to-order dishes were hit or miss. The meat was decent, but I‚Äôm not into wagyu. I prefer american ribeye which was good. Dessert options were limited, and honestly, the taste wasn‚Äôt great. I‚Äôd rather go to Chubby Cattle and pay half the price for a better experience. Was meh. Menu online mentioned  139$ came with tomahawk steak. The only availability was 139$. 3 people paid for 139$ and only received 1 tomahawk steak. The waiter was doing good when it wasn't busy, but the service went down dramatically once it got busy ( the server started spilling water from a bottle of water you pay 9$ for). Buffet food was good, but only if it was available when you were in line (multiple items i was looking for were not available about 60-70% of the time I went to the buffet line). We ordered 3 chefs special sashimi platter (came with the 139$, and was one per person) we received one bowl. There was not one piece per person (the platter was presented nicely though). For the price you pay (99$/139$), I would expect food to be readily available consistently and better service. I would not go back. If I can rate this place as 0/5 I would. I was utterly appalled and frankly disappointed in this establishment. If you want cheaper AYCE wagyu/sushi, I think driving to one of their sister restaurants is more cost efficient (such as Yumiyaki, Mikiya, or even Chubby Cattle). Those other restaurants are cheaper and judging by how they serve sushi and Japanese Wagyu also, it's better to get those dishes there than pay a butt load for this place.

We got the upgraded option of $139, and opted out to order any large steaks that you pre- order (ex. tomahawks range from 35-40 oz, and some other options that you can select of your choosing.

Service: Extremely horrendous. I had runners/staff members not even know the simple aspect of having certain condiments at their restaurant. One runner said they didn't have tabasco, but had chili oil; only for a FOH manager to come by and say they have no tabasco and chili oil. Our server kept getting our orders wrong which caused a delay in our meat being served because we were sat at a non-grill table. Our server admitted to getting the orders wrong completely. Wait was over 15-20 minutes long in between waiting for the next round. Runners/servers also kept serving dishes on the side of the table even if there was room in the middle of the table. Dishes were not cleaned up. I had almost 4 plates stacked just from appetizers because I was starving between rounds of meat never coming essentially.

Ambiance: The restaurant is nice, but with the amount of complaining tables surrounding our area, I definitely didn't think that I was at a high end semi fancy restaurant at all. Interior is dark and nice, but the buffet line could use some work as it is a narrow walkway and some patrons decide to stand and block the way as well.

Food: Subpar at best. If I wanted to get expensive cut meat and be paying for 139 for it, I should be getting top quality. It was lukewarm at minimum every time we received the meat. It wasn't cooked to our medium rare liking, and some of the meats weren't the ones we ordered since our server got out order wrong multiple times.

Manager Education: Its pretty comical when even the managers of this establishment aren't well trained, couldn't answer simple questions of why the wait was taking so long, why the service was horrible, and why the raw seafood bar was completely barren for a great portion of the time. When we asked these questions, they completely invalidated our party and didn't try to resolve the solution or provide alternatives in any way possible. Pretty disappointing for a restaurant group that I've had pretty adequate experiences at their other sister restaurants.

Overall, I am not stepping into this establishment again. This wasn't even half of the entire experience. I saw an influencer table get up and not touch their food or pay at all, and then another couple order the tomahawk and have a few bites and left, and then the table that got seated after they left also got up and complained why the food was delayed and the service was pretty unbearable. I advise eating at their sister restaurants for much cheaper like chubby cattle, yumiyaki, or even mikiya. At least you'll pay for the service you're getting and the quality of food. One of the worst experiences ever and to top it off, I sent an email to their feedback group and they promised they would get back in 48 hours, and they never got back to me :(. Save your money, and your wrinkles on this place. Service Dine in Meal type Dinner Price per person $100+ Food: 1 Service: 1 Atmosphere: 1

The food was terrible, and each dish took at least 15 minutes to prepare. At 139 yuan, this buffet is absolutely not worth the price. The service was also awful. They gave us a tiny table, and after we finished eating, no one came to clear our plates; we had to call them multiple times before they came. If you want to order drinks, remember, they are extra, and the staff won't tell you! The only difference between the 99 and 139 yuan buffets is that you can only order one of four dishes per person, and each serving only contains two pieces of food. Almost all the seafood was very stale; the only decent thing was the cake. We had to find a server three times and waited over ten minutes to pay the bill. A truly awful experience! We had a reservation with the full service package  for 8:30 pm. We arived at 8:25 and was told to wait outside and that they would call us in.

We got our table at 9:05 just and was informed that the kitchen would close at 10:30pm. When our server later on told us that last call is at 10 because the kitchen is closing we got surprised.

This ment that our session that would be 2 hours from start now in reality only was 45 min. We had prebooked months ahead and was really looking forward to try this place, the disappointment is quite huge

The food we got to try was really good, i would recommend to take the 99 option were you have the opportunity to grill the meat yourself.

So overall it is with a visit but if possible try to book an early sitting so that you have plenty of time.

We had a reservation at 8. We were late to be seated and had placed order for drinks at the bar. We had to follow up 3 times, the drinks were still not ready. The drinks came out only after we had already been seated at the table. Even then we still had to follow up on one of the drinks as it did not arrive. None of the items were refilled, there were no dessert items left at all, we were able to try just 1 round of wagyu because they were not refilled. Nothing is refilled so there were times the group was just watching for refills. Very disappointing that they claim this is ayce but then don't refill any of the items. The quality was excellent when the items were refilled but I could've had a better experience just paying a la carte instead of waiting like scavengers. Disappointing to hear that others got free champagne for a birthday while we were given nothing. I do not recommend coming her after 8 because it seems like they do not refill after then. Honest Experience at Niku X in LA (900 Wilshire)
First time 9/28/24

I had high hopes for Niku X, but the overall experience was quite disappointing. First off, much of the food was served cold and lacked flavor. The dipping sauces were sparse, and the tomahawk steak, which we expected to be a showstopper, was not only small for a table of six but also had burnt ends.

The crab legs were served cold as well, and the garlic butter tasted like it had no garlic in it at all. Even the hot meats were completely unseasoned, which was a huge letdown. This is far from what I‚Äôd expect from a restaurant claiming Michelin star-level quality.

Another issue was the table itself‚Äîit was far too small for the number of people and dishes. Plates and cups were constantly bumping into each other, which made the meal feel cramped and uncomfortable. For a fine dining experience, you‚Äôd think the space would be better suited for the number of dishes they serve.

On the positive side, our waitress Wissal was wonderful, and her service was top-notch. No complaints there. However, I was annoyed to find that we were charged for water without being informed in advance. I don‚Äôt mind paying, but a heads-up would‚Äôve been nice.

The drinks were strong, but at the price point they charge, you'd expect nothing less. In the end, Niku X did not live up to the Michelin star standards they claim to meet. For the cost, the experience left a lot to be desired.

STAY AWAY!! RUN, DON‚ÄôT WALK!!

We visited on 8/31 for the AYCE tasting menu for $99 and it was a big disappointment in all aspects.

To start off we had a reservation on OpenTable for 7:30PM and we arrived at 7:25PM only to wait an additional hour until we were sat.

The AYCE selection was mostly absent, the walk up bar for food was empty most of the night. Only American wagyu options were available in the fridge, no Japanese wagyu AT ALL. Crudo station was empty with exception of a few small dishes being set out occasionally that would go quickly. NO KING CRAB was ever available on any of our visits to the buffet line.

While eating, my wife bit into a small plastic bead pictured below which appears to be a hair bead that was somehow fallen into the food she ate. Absolutely disgusting!!!

As for the service, it was also atrocious!! Once we were sat, we ordered waters for the table and a kids cup for my son. My wife and I received our water but our son‚Äôs never came so we asked again. Wait 20min, still no water so we ask again. We wait again no one comes to the table to check on us or asks if we need anything until 20min later when a bus boy comes around and asks and we finally got the water for my son 40minutes after we got ours. After this, I walked to the host stand to speak to the manager about how we were upset about the food/water situation and was told that a manager would be sent over but guess what? No manager ever showed. We then asked for our check through the bus boy and waited roughly 15min before asking again because no one ever brought it. A manager was finally brought our check and we made him aware of the situation. Manager was very apologetic and offered to comp one of our meals.

I would never visit this establishment again nor would I ever recommend it.

STAY AWAY AND EAT ELSEWHERE!!!!! Service Dine in Meal type Dinner Price per person $100+ Food: 1 Service: 1 Atmosphere: 1

Careful about believing online hype. Checked this place out because of the buzz on social media.

We arrived at our designated reservation time and were told it‚Äôs going to be a short wait because they are just cleaning tables. I had to check three times with the front desk only to be seated after 45 minutes because the front of house had to set up our table herself.

Now for the buffet selection, some items were already out of stock like oysters and fried rice. The steaks also took time to replenish. Very disappointed that they also ran out of the A5 wagyu which is one of the main reasons people go to this place. From the hot menu, the lamb chop and katsu sandwich (which is what most people talk about online) were also sold out!

The service left much to be desired as well as our drinks took forever to arrive and when we asked for another round of iced tea ‚Äî they ran out (how does this happen?).

Will probably not go back after this experience. Food: 3 Service: 1 Atmosphere: 3

We originally had a 7:15 reservation on Friday July 12 and once we checked in, we were told that there were a few tables ahead of us and we could wait in the waiting area/lobby. We assumed it would be a 10-15 minute wait but 30 minutes had already passed before any type of update. We spoke to one of the front managers and he had apologized for the wait but did not have an estimated time for the next available table. He offered us the regular menu to order some appetizers while we were still waiting in the lobby, so we had placed an order for 2 Japanese Albacore with Crispy Onion handrolls to tide over our appetite. We were waiting roughly for 10-15 minutes for our order, but thankfully we were called for an open table.

We were finally seated at 8:15pm and immediately placed our food order for the DineLA menu. We received our first order of the crudo along with our order of the 2 albacore handrolls at 8:22pm. We quickly devoured those 2 items after waiting an hour to be seated. We were waiting on our next course but we did not receive it until 8:49pm. We received our Dashi Yukke Soup at a warm but not hot temperature and 27 minutes after our first course.

At this point, we were extremely hungry and disappointed in the level of execution and service at the restaurant. To wait nearly 30 minutes in between each course was completely absurd. If we continued with the same pace, our dinner would last 2 hours and we would end our dinner at 10pm. We spoke with the manager and he apologized for the wait and offered to ask the chef if they could expedite the rest of our menu. We then got the rest of the menu (Chimichurri Bone Marrow and A5 Wagyu Yakiniku) 10 minutes later. We also received the Fried Brussel Sprouts on the house.

To conclude dinner, they also sent over 2 desserts. We appreciated that they were able to comp the handrolls, brussel sprouts, and desserts for all the inconvenience. Once we received the check, the manager came over again to apologize for the wait and offered us a 15% service discount. We left the restaurant after paying.

I started feeling some stomach pains once we left the restaurant. I confided with my friend who I had ate with and she had also had slight stomach pains. On my drive home, I started to feel nauseous and knew it was definitely from something I had eaten. My friend later confided in me that she started feeling the same way around 4am. We felt horrible and found out that we both got food poisoning. We both concluded that it must have been something we had both eaten at the restaurant since we both had similar symptoms. We are both extremely disappointed in the whole experience given that Niku X holds such a high standard for food and experience. Disappointing Experience and Dangerous Mix-Up

This is the first time in my life I felt the need to write a bad review

We visited NIKU X for dinner and were deeply disappointed by the service. Despite their last call being at 10 PM, we arrived at 9:50 PM and were promptly informed that food orders needed to be placed before 10 PM. We quickly placed our order at 9:55 PM.

However, when we ordered our drinks, the bartender's attitude was less than welcoming. My partner, who is allergic to alcohol, ordered a non-alcoholic drink, while I ordered an alcoholic one. The bartender clearly did not want to make our drinks as they were preparing to close.

When our drinks were served, my partner's non-alcoholic drink contained alcohol. This could have been disastrous if we hadn't realized in time, especially considering my partner's allergy. Fortunately, we lived upstairs, but had she been the designated driver, this mistake could have put us in a very difficult situation.

After waiting for half an hour, the manager approached us to inform us that due to a miscommunication, the kitchen was unable to prepare our food. He offered to pay for our drinks and said he would see what leftovers were available in the kitchen to serve us. Offering leftovers after making us wait for half an hour is simply unacceptable. We were extremely hungry after being out all day, and they could have informed us much sooner so we could have found somewhere else to eat.

Overall, this experience was incredibly disappointing and potentially dangerous due to the mix-up with the drinks. We hope the management addresses these serious issues to prevent future incidents. Service Dine in Meal type Dinner Food: 1 Service: 1 Atmosphere: 2

Today was the first time in a while where I realized I am ONLY an Asian living in LA.

From the moment me and my visiting friend sat down at the table, the waitress handed over menus with some sass.

Two of us ordered, one appetizer, four entrees, and two drinks, which came out to be $402.

Starting with the appetizer, food came out one at a time. One of the dishes we ordered was sashimi platter. After putting the dish on the table, explaining the platter, the waiter from the kitchen, accidentally touched/ poked the food. He tried to laugh off by saying ‚Äúahahahahh,‚Ä¶ oh my gosh~~ I‚Äôm so sorryyyy~.‚Äù Then he walked away. It‚Äôs a lawsuit. The fact that he touched a raw fish then walked away laughing without even offering to bring out a fresh new plate was the first red flag.

And to continue with the sashimi, it was the worst sashimi I had in my life. Not only was it not fresh, the color, texture, the way it was sliced‚Ä¶ the food was done at a level that could have been done by a teenager at home.

Then when entrees started coming out, the waitress came over to move around plates on the table to make some space. As she was doing so, she spilled a bowl of soy sauce on the table and into my wasabi bowl. The sauce nearly missed my white jacket. When I asked the waitress to wipe the soy sauce, she said she will get it wiped without even an apology.

Lastly the $180 kobe striploin was such a waste of money. 40% was fat, not even from marbling, but just excessive fat that should have been taken care of in the kitchen.

Out of five dishes we ordered, we only finished one, which was wagyu tartare. Wagyu fried rice, we didn‚Äôt even attempt to taste it as it looked like a microwaved frozen beef rice.

At last the manager came over to ask what was unsatisfying about the meal. When I told him everything including some other details not included in this review, he took the two plates of sashimi and the wagyu fried rice out from the check.

Simultaneously he gave me his business card saying the next time I make a visit he will provide special course menu + explained how some of their sashimis are dry aged, causing them to not ‚Äúlook‚Äù fresh. Listen, this isn‚Äôt my first day on this planet eating dry aged sashimi. The fact that the manager tried to cover up the whole unsettling experience with his story of dry aged sashimi shows he himself doesn‚Äôt have the basics down as for a manager.

It is very hard to believe that this restaurant is even on the Michelin guide. Service Dine in Meal type Dinner Price per person $100+ Food: 2 Service: 2 Atmosphere: 3 Recommended dishes

do you know how bad a place has to be in order for someone who has never submitted a review to feel compelled to write one up mere minutes after eating? you would think being on the michelin guide meant something. i have never felt more robbed by a restaurant.

let me try to paint a picture. we arrive for an 8PM reservation only to wait 20 minutes to be seated in a nowhere near full restaurant. i watch later parties be seated by the same staff that has walked by me multiple times. i have to ask the hostess if anyone planned to seat me, to her surprise.

at this point, you see the rolling robots that bring drinks and dishes to tables. it‚Äôs the kind of thing that feels cute in a small sushi joint, but feels tone-deaf in a giant upscale restaurant with tons of staff that is marketing a five-star experience.

i attempt to order sake to pair with this meal. no luck. this alleged high-end japanese wagyu joint is somehow out of nearly every sake on the list. the beverage director has to come to our table to recommend a bottle - as if they or i had a choice.

we came for the a la carte menu but decided to try the ‚Äúpremium‚Äù tasting menu thinking it‚Äôd be worth the price. we couldn‚Äôt have been more wrong.

for starters, why am i able to smell the bluefish tuna ‚Äúcrudu‚Äù (server‚Äôs words, not mine) and why does it taste fishy? the scallop was somehow cooked enough to develop a inedible outside layer. the caviar and potage are good but that in and of itself is very hard to mess up. there is no brine to the caviar and the popcorn added to the potage is gimmicky. amateur hour at a restaurant of this purported level.

you‚Äôll learn that the staff is instructed to tell you where everything is from - australian this, african that. so much so that the kimchi persian cucumber is somehow from japan. you think you came to experience japanese barbecue only to be served banchan and pregrilled vegetables slathered in sauce.

we go through 3 rounds of grilled meat and every single one of them is tough, chewy, and flavorless. it is the last 3 meats they serve where you think ‚Äúfinally‚Äù‚Ä¶ this is what you came for. the server will tell you to pick from your choice of ribeye, striploin, or kobe as your final course. he‚Äôll fail to mention that the kobe is an extra charge added to your already extremely overpriced meal.

we asked for chocolate cake and cheesecake for the dessert, but instead we got lavender cake. in our server‚Äôs words ‚Äúthis is on us.‚Äù what generosity! can someone explain how that is possible on a pre fixe meal?

i have to laugh at this entire experience to keep from feeling completely taken for a fool. absolutely nothing about this place is premium. save yourself the time and money by dining elsewhere. anywhere in sawtelle or koreatown runs laps around this overhyped and overpriced restaurant. when multiple servers pronounce wagyu as ‚Äúwa-goo‚Äù, run. Food was good. Everything served in the tasting menu was fine.

Our dinner service started with the wait staff fumbling around with the table grill for 20 mins. After 5 or 6 people couldn't figure it out, someone finally came and fixed it. No apologies from staff, mgmt, or even an acknowledgement of the inconvenience. Then grill itself then was too hot and all of our meats and fish kept getting stuck to it. Pretty inexcusable when you're charging several hundred dollars for single portions.

Rather disappointed with the overall experience since it is regarded so highly. Food: 4 Service: 1 Atmosphere: 1

I headed they had been added to the Michelin guide, and I love Wagyu, so  I was excited to try their food. Unfortunately, the place was Beyond Overrated! We tried the 14-course menu, and some pieces were okay, but nothing was great. Their Wagyu A4 was their best piece (really good). Although, for an unusual reason, they added Blueberry sauce to their A5, which DESTROYED the meat's taste. It reminded me of a blueberry pancake. Such a waste of good meat.

The drinks were all right, and we liked them. Ambiance 3 stars (it wasn't bad, nothing unique. they had some artwork on a wall), service 1 star (empty glasses of water, multiple dishes on the table, I don't even want to start with napkins and everything else), Value 1 star (it would be acceptable for around $150-$200 not for $400). Overall, 2,3 stars for a high-end restaurant.

Btw if you are a vegetarian, don't get close to that place. They were dishonest about their offering (really disappointing). They charged the same price of $300ish ($400 with drinks/tip) for their veggie option (which wasn't even 5,6 courses compared to 14), and it was the worst veggie we had ever tried in any place in LA. We go to restaurants a lot. Most have been honest about their offering, for example, M√©lisse Restaurant, 2 Michelin stars; when I called them, they said they were sorry but couldn't accommodate Vegetarians, and I appreciated their honesty. They didn't try to rob us.

Should you go? If you have been to all high-end restaurants in LA, including Michelin restaurants (because that is what you are paying), and a lack of quality, service, and details doesn't bother you much, you can try this too.

I pay $400, sometimes even more, in many restaurants (including 3-star Michelin worldwide), and I am okay with spending that money for experience and greatness. Not because I have too much money to burn, which I don't. I had great experiences (and also some disappointing ones) throughout my journey. This restaurant was one of my worst experiences in any high-end restaurant (above the $250 range). Service Dine in Meal type Dinner Price per person $100+

Most have been honest about their offering, for example, M√©lisse Restaurant, 2 Michelin stars; when I called them, they said they were sorry but couldn't accommodate Vegetarians, and I appreciated their honesty. They didn't try to rob us.

Should you go? If you have been to all high-end restaurants in LA, including Michelin restaurants (because that is what you are paying), and a lack of quality, service, and details doesn't bother you much, you can try this too.

I pay $400, sometimes even more, in many restaurants (including 3-star Michelin worldwide), and I am okay with spending that money for experience and greatness. Not because I have too much money to burn, which I don't. I had great experiences (and also some disappointing ones) throughout my journey. This restaurant was one of my worst experiences in any high-end restaurant (above the $250 range). Service Dine in Meal type Dinner Price per person $100+

I headed they had been added to the Michelin guide, and I love Wagyu, so  I was excited to try their food. Unfortunately, the place was Beyond Overrated! We tried the 14-course menu, and some pieces were okay, but nothing was great. Their Wagyu A4 was their best piece (really good). Although, for an unusual reason, they added Blueberry sauce to their A5, which DESTROYED the meat's taste. It reminded me of a blueberry pancake. Such a waste of good meat.

The drinks were all right, and we liked them. Ambiance 3 stars (it wasn't bad, nothing unique. they had some artwork on a wall), service 1 star (empty glasses of water, multiple dishes on the table, I don't even want to start with napkins and everything else), Value 1 star (it would be acceptable for around $150-$200 not for $400). Overall, 2,3 stars for a high-end restaurant.

Went here last night for my birthday dinner. Dinner came out to $650 for the two of us and at that price point, service should be top tier. It wasn‚Äôt. I‚Äôm surprised Chef Shin Thompson held a previous Michelin Star & overlooked the service. I never write reviews but last night‚Äôs service really pains me.

Service: Generous 1/5

1. Our menus when we sat down were bent and dirty (they‚Äôre printed on cardstock I‚Äôve bought at Michael‚Äôs). The courses also don‚Äôt follow the order of what comes out which was confusing
2. They don‚Äôt have purse or coat hooks so i was already like huh?? My purse fell on the floor & our jackets fell like 3x
3. Food Pacing- they dropped 4 dishes at once so by the time it was time for our soup, it was barely luke warm. Also, why don‚Äôt they have soup spoons? It was SO HARD to drink the soup. Bevel was so wide you couldn‚Äôt sip from the bowl.
4. They never changed our utensils. I had to ask constantly & they often left me without a knife ‚Ä¶ at a yakiniku restaurant. Also, I‚Äôm not going to slice into a beautiful cut of beef with a knife covered in fish juices or blueberry jam?
5. They put the scallop onto a plate with trash on it hahahah (leftover lemon from the dish prior)
6. When our server opened the box for the beef she walked away without even explaining what was what. I had to ask someone else walking by. This blew my mind & I have video of it. I spent majority of my dinner listening to the server at the table next to us. He did a much better job. Overheard him saying the $10 upcharge for the A5 ribeye would be a hotpot and I was like ‚Ä¶ huh, how was that never mentioned to us?
7. They didn‚Äôt even refill my water. I pushed my glass out as far as possible & couldn‚Äôt refill my own water unless I got up from my seat. Lastly, at the end of dinner they ignored my empty glass and grabbed the check right next to it. I was fuming. REFILL WATER. PLEASE. We paid $9 and we weren‚Äôt offered ‚Äúhouse‚Äù aka tap.

Food reviews:

Seafood: 2/5
Half the tasting menu was seafood (this surprised me). Majority of the seafood didn‚Äôt taste very clean, maybe I‚Äôm too spoiled having gone to places like n/naka. The scallop with uni butter would be a 5/5- that item saved the night.

Meats: 4/5
Maybe closer to a 3.5? We‚Äôll round up because the sauces were amazing. Good meats should be able to stand alone though- I‚Äôm not sure these would have. Most of the pieces were melty but still very chewy (cartilage/muscle). I wish we‚Äôd gone to a butcher and picked up an A5 Ribeye to make at home.

At least they brought out a happy birthday sign on my dessert. Don‚Äôt be like me and fall for the IG ads ‚Ä¶ Props to their marketing team. Neutral.Context:
Niku x has gone through many changes over the years, some certainly positive. What would elevate them to a luxurious high-end Japanese restaurant rather a regular Japanese bbq buffet that offers wagyu would be if their meats were cut thicker, even if they were the same ounce. Small or even limited portions would be fair at such a deal, but sacrificing quality of the meats potential doesn‚Äôt feel right. The in-between awkwardly thin meats make it impossible to have a pink center. The meat will always be either over cooked or appear boiled. If ur going to have wagyu, gotta do it right!
Other than that, the service is amazing and the other bites prepared to order are amazing, especially the seabass wrap! Food: 3 Service: 5 Atmosphere: 4

Atmosphere: 4

All and all, my friends and I had a a decent experience here.  Our waiter was wonderful, and the atmosphere was nice.  The food was okay. Some items were really good and others were just fine. I wouldnt be upset if friends wanted to come here, but I'm not rushing back.   ALWAYS ASK FOR THE ITEMIZED  RECEIPT and review it - We had some errors with our bill that I had to call fix when I got home. They did fix it though. I recently went to NIKU X Los Angeles, which is on the 2nd floor of the Intercontinental Hotel.

The place has a beautiful ambience‚Äîclean, classy, and perfect for a nice night out.
They offer valet parking and validate for 2.5 hours, but since we had three cars, we still ended up paying almost $100 extra after the free hours. For just over an hour of staying‚Äîdining, picture-taking, and exploring the hotel‚Äîit felt a bit pricey just for parking.

When it comes to the food, they have two options: $109 per person and $149 per person.

The $109 already includes unlimited lobster, seafood, beef, sushi, sashimi, and more from the buffet.
The $149 option is marketed as the ‚Äúpremium experience,‚Äù with unlimited Japanese A5 Wagyu and a few other special dishes.

We decided to go for the $149 option for the experience.
The unlimited Wagyu sounds great, but to be honest, it was underwhelming.
If you‚Äôve had authentic Japanese A5 Wagyu before, you‚Äôd know the taste and quality are usually outstanding even without seasoning.
But here, it just didn‚Äôt have that same melt-in-your-mouth flavor.

For me, it felt overpriced and not really worth the hype.
Meanwhile, the ‚Äúspecial seafood‚Äù at $149‚Äîlike king crab legs, shrimp with caviar, and a few other items‚Äîare only served once, not unlimited.

The best part of the evening was actually the ambience and the service.
Our server Naomi was amazing‚Äîfriendly, attentive, and she explained everything so clearly.
She really made my birthday celebration special.

Overall, if you‚Äôre a seafood lover, I‚Äôd say just go with the $109 option.
You already get plenty‚Äîlobster, shrimp, sushi, sashimi, and more‚Äîwithout spending extra on Wagyu that doesn‚Äôt really stand out.

The $149 feels too expensive for what it offers. The place is definitely beautiful, the service is excellent, but next time I‚Äôd probably just stick with the $109‚Äîor maybe try another spot.

The best part of the evening was actually the ambience and the service.
Our server Naomi was amazing‚Äîfriendly, attentive, and she explained everything so clearly.
She really made my birthday celebration special.

Overall, if you‚Äôre a seafood lover, I‚Äôd say just go with the $109 option.
You already get plenty‚Äîlobster, shrimp, sushi, sashimi, and more‚Äîwithout spending extra on Wagyu that doesn‚Äôt really stand out.

The $149 feels too expensive for what it offers. The place is definitely beautiful, the service is excellent, but next time I‚Äôd probably just stick with the $109‚Äîor maybe try another spot.

The wives planned birthday dinner for a total of 3 very hungry dads.  We went with the Tomahawk menu.

A few things in random order:

1.) Location is great and so is the decor.
2.) We were seated promptly (a Thursday).  Party of 6 but they don't really have any rectangular tables so we sat in 1 square and 1 circular table so we could all fit.  That was odd and annoying.
3.)  Service is slow.   The place was not busy but the server would disappear for awhile.  I know it's a buffet but restaurants make $$ on drinks moreso than anything else.
4.) The drinks were....meh.   I was looking for a fancy old fashion or mule.  Instead the drink menu had 6 or 7 l drinks and it seemed all pre-made and some slushy style with alcohol.  (Felt cheap) Not a fancy menu at all for the top dollar being spent.  The wine was good but came in a bottle (lol)
5.) Seafood options - Lobster, Tiger/large shrimp, sushi.  These options were good - however - I would go elsewhere and eat that as a separate meal.
6.) The Tomahawk was ok.   We ordered 1 per couple.  It was too much because that should've been a separate meal as well.  Instead of eating buffet/unlimited seafood and a big tomahawk.   It would've been better to eat twice there at a more modest price.  (That was our bad)
7.) The Tomahawk "show" to wow us.  Meh... maybe because I got older and it was a repeat of a past experience.  We had 3 Tomahawks and got 1 show.   We had to share the first Tomahawk because they didn't bring us the other 2 until 30 mins later.   Again restaurant was not busy at all.
8.) The bill.  The bill came and certain items that were comped because of the birthday were not.  They were charged. Also, when they fixed it they taxed us on the FULL amount vs the subtotal.  Their excuse was that the item was "prepared" so it's still taxable.  Lastly on the bill.  The tip was automatically included on again the full amount including the items comped.   So where they comped???  It all was corrected after their frustration.  Table was full of numbers people so.....yeah.  Saved $30 per person...worth it.

Overall, the spot is nice and the food ok for the price point and experience.

Go once and say you went.

If you go don't do the Tomahawk.  Get at the A5 if you can and balance that with the seafood.

From seeing all the reviews and recommendations from YouTube, I have to say, the whole experience was somewhat a letdown, given the cost to dine here.

The entire setup of the restaurant is definitely not suitable for a get up and grab your own food style buffet and the selection to grab is also very limited. It was honestly a weird experience since the menu itself is actually pretty standard in size, but the presentation and idea to get up to grab the food from the serving area was awkward.

You would have to wait for a refresh of new food to grab, and given that the restaurant had a decent size, felt somewhat awkward when there wasn't any food left, or very few left to grab.

Some of the appetizers were pretty good, but others were really surprisingly lackluster. The ceviche that is always offered has a very bland flavor, it felt like it was missing some core flavor profiles.

For the price of $100+ before tax and tip, I honestly felt like I could've went anywhere else for this price and had a more positive memorable meal. We visited NIKU X for a special Mother‚Äôs Day lunch with my mom and my mom‚Äôs boyfriend‚Äôs daughter-in-law. While the restaurant definitely looks upscale and visually impressive, the experience unfortunately didn‚Äôt live up to expectations.

Service was a major letdown. It felt like we were lucky just to get our waiter‚Äôs attention during the entire meal. For a place that presents itself as fine dining, the level of attention and hospitality was severely lacking.

As for the food, the meats were just okay‚Äînothing special or memorable. The buffet selection was very limited, especially considering the high price point. What‚Äôs worse is that the lunch menu doesn‚Äôt offer the variety or quality you‚Äôd expect compared to dinner, yet it‚Äôs still expensive.

For what we paid, I expected top-tier meats and exceptional service. Instead, we left feeling disappointed and like the whole experience was overpriced for what little was offered. I wouldn‚Äôt recommend coming here for lunch, especially if you‚Äôre expecting the kind of selection and service that should come with a premium price tag. First of all, the food is good and fresh but the dining experience will be good ONLY IF you reserve the right menu option. We had the $159/person menu Without Grill on table  although the menu we got as well as the web clearly says $149/person( kind of misleading). First round we tried the JP A5 Ribeyes and Striploin which both melts in your mouth with an aroma that is indeed A grade JP Wagyu beef. We also grab some crab legs from the station and crab meat is warm and fresh. Everything seems to be good for the first 30 minutes and then things went south. It took them 30 minutes to get the 2nd round of the Wagyu steak from the kitchen AFTER we complained to the waiter for wait 20 minutes for nothing. Although the waiter and the manager did manage to get the steak speed up later on, even offering free drinks, we ended up with lots of Wagyu steaks on the table at the same time and it soon became too overwhelming while eating too much oily steak for such a short period of time. Till the end, we realized that we never even get the lobster tail we ordered earlier while they will never forget your appetizers. As for the dessert, they have a limited selection of cake flavors. Make sure you order the ones you like in between the dining otherwise you might not be able to get the flavor you want at the end. Overall, crab labs are good, shrimp is okay,  sashimi is average but at least they all taste fresh. A5 Wagyu only the Premium 5 oz Wagyu Worth the try but not the special Wagyu cut. If you like seafood, just go with the basic menu option. If you want Wagyu, make sure you reserve the table WITH GRILL or you will get GRILLED. By the way, for the owner, you need to update your website about the pricing otherwise it is misleading for the table with or without a grill. It took them 30 minutes to get the 2nd round of the Wagyu steak from the kitchen AFTER we complained to the waiter for wait 20 minutes for nothing. Although the waiter and the manager did manage to get the steak speed up later on, even offering free drinks, we ended up with lots of Wagyu steaks on the table at the same time and it soon became too overwhelming while eating too much oily steak for such a short period of time. Till the end, we realized that we never even get the lobster tail we ordered earlier while they will never forget your appetizers. As for the dessert, they have a limited selection of cake flavors. Make sure you order the ones you like in between the dining otherwise you might not be able to get the flavor you want at the end. Overall, crab labs are good, shrimp is okay,  sashimi is average but at least they all taste fresh. A5 Wagyu only the Premium 5 oz Wagyu Worth the try but not the special Wagyu cut. If you like seafood, just go with the basic menu option. If you want Wagyu, make sure you reserve the table WITH GRILL or you will get GRILLED. By the way, for the owner, you need to update your website about the pricing otherwise it is misleading for the table with or without a grill. I had high expectations after reading all the great reviews, so I made a reservation in mid-October. The earliest available weekend slot for a party of four was late December, so I waited almost three months for this visit. I was really looking forward to it.

But maybe my expectations were too high. I thought we would have a table where we could grill the meat ourselves, but our seats were at the bar near the windows. The ventilation was excellent, but it caused the meat to cool down very quickly, and we ended up eating everything cold.

Another disappointing point was the lack of customization for how the meat was cooked. I prefer medium-rare, while my group prefers well-done, but I had no choice but to eat everything well-done. If we had been seated at a grilling table, I would have ordered medium-rare and cooked it to my preference.

When asked why I didn‚Äôt complain, it‚Äôs because it was my first visit, and I assumed the seating was assigned and grilling tables weren‚Äôt an option for us. However, my friends later told me that they were able to grill their meat and enjoy it warm. It was disappointing, especially after waiting three months for this experience.

We ordered the $139menu, but due to the holiday season, the price had increased by $10.

That said, the service was exceptional. The servers were attentive, offering sample dishes, small cocktails, and even soju, which made the experience fun. The bar was clean, and the sushi and crab were absolutely delicious.

In conclusion, while the meat was disappointing, the other aspects of the meal were satisfying. If you plan to visit, I recommend opting for the $99 menu instead. I have mixed feelings about Niki X‚Äôs buffet. There is no doubt that the cuts are high quality and luxurious, but the meal wasn‚Äôt exactly enjoyable or delicious. There was an extreme lack of side dishes that you would  expect of a buffet. There was no fruit and very little vegetable options. Dessert options sucked. This meant you had nothing to balance out the extremely fatty cuts. Maybe it‚Äôs because they were not originally designed to be a buffet so they had very little space to spread the food items available for self-service, but the result is one feel almost sickened by the heaviness of the meal at the end of it.

They were also blasting k-pop music which, while I normally enjoy, did not really help in creating a ‚Äúpremium‚Äù experience because they were intentionally picked to be upbeat and high-speed songs. These songs are more suited for a bar or fast food setting and I felt like the choice was to rush customers out of the door.

Service left me a little confused. Everyone was professional, but they did not have an option for coat check in a closet when the entire restaurant is very smoky from the grill. The seating was also pretty weird; if you go as two people you have to sit next to each other which can become pretty crowded.

First, let me say that my husband and I traveled from Texas to celebrate our Birthday at this restaurant. He is a seafood foodie so it was one of his special birthday requests to fly to LA and eat here. The atmosphere was dimly lit, kind of intimate in appearance however you are seated with others and not at a private table. The music was a bit loud so conversation had to be louder. We had an amazing waiter JJ who was nothing but TOP NOTCH all night long!! The food was not worth the price unfortunately üòï. The seafood was cold seafood. I'm used to my crab legs being hot and boiled with flavor. My husband loves all kinds hot or cold seafood and he said it was sub par. The Wagyu Beef requires a special pallette because it was very greasy. And the desserts were not sweet at all and were just horrible. I felt really cheated on what was supposed to be a superior experience! And for the cost of this experience....when you travel this far for a birthday experience....well let's just say I am super disappointed. Our waiter sent over the manager, who was super nice and very understanding, provided an alternative for food options, however we were really already over it. He provided us a 60$ discount which still made the experience cost 160$ plus the 16.50 for parking. I do not recommend this experience unless you specifically like cold seafood and wagyu beef. But i will always recommend JJ our waiter! Thank you guys and hope this helps! Food: 1 Service: 5 Atmosphere: 3

Things you should know:

The beef quality was good, but largely raw and the only seasonings available to you are pepper and salts.

The lobster tails were tiny (not much larger than some large prawns) but that's okay because it's all you can eat. The king crab was smaller than average but again, okay because all you can eat.

Aside from the wagyu, lobster, and crab, there actually isn't much else to enjoy so come here with that in mind.

Lobster, king crab and large head prawns are only served cold.

Not all tables get to grill food on their own. Sometimes you can get seated at a table where everything must be cooked for you by a kitchen.

Some items are one order per person, including their most premium dishes like the ones that have uni or caviar, which is presumably some of their most expensive items.

They no longer have the bone marrow.

Despite making reservations weeks in advance and informing them of a birthday, they ran out of their caviar/uni/sashimi dish which is limited per guest.

You can order grilled king crab but it's one per person (weird, just grill it yourself at your table, if you've got a table with a grill).

Drinks are not ayce including soft drinks.

Our server was great though. Service Dine in Meal type Dinner Price per person $100+ Food: 3 Service: 5 Atmosphere: 5

We‚Äôve been dining at Niku X for the past nine months, and each visit continues to impress. This is easily one of the best high-end dining experiences in Los Angeles.

The A5 Wagyu is the undisputed highlight‚Äîexpertly grilled tableside, incredibly tender, and full of rich flavor. We‚Äôre also big fans of the shrimp and lobster tails‚Äîalways fresh and satisfying. Don‚Äôt miss the Miso Chilean Seabass wrap (ordered separately)‚Äîa buttery, melt-in-your-mouth bite that‚Äôs absolutely worth it.

We first met Cody at the Little Tokyo Chubby Cattle location and were happy to see him here. He always makes us feel welcome‚Äîlike a friend ensuring we enjoy every aspect of the meal. Wilson was our main server and was fantastic throughout‚Äîattentive, professional, and warm.

One note: premium seafood items like king crab and lobster tails are replenished on a schedule. At this price point, continuous availability would be more fitting. Also, pre-shelled lobster tail would improve the overall dining ease.

We‚Äôve been Chubby Club members for a few months now, and it‚Äôs a great value for those who dine here often. Valet parking with validation is currently $24 (up from $16.50 nine months ago), still reasonable considering the regular $54 rate without validation.

Reservations are highly recommended‚Äîuse OpenTable to secure a spot. The dining experience is limited to 120 minutes, so plan accordingly.

Exceptional food, top-tier service, and a sleek, modern ambiance make Niku X a must-try. We‚Äôll absolutely be back. I recently dined at Niku X and had a positive experience overall. The wagyu was fantastic, the seafood was mostly very delicious, and the sides that you order from the kitchen were all very good as well. Being a huge seafood fan, I was primarily interested in eating the various fish and shellfish options. While I really enjoyed 90% of the seafood selection, I will say that the crab and lobster were a bit underwhelming. One of the crabs (can't remember which kind) was very salty, while the lobster had a somewhat rubbery texture. Aside from the seafood, the beef options were all fantastic and melt-in-your-mouth. The cocktails were well-made and delicious, but seemed light on alcohol. We also ordered a couple of soft drinks, which were fairly expensive and not a good value ($6 for a tiny glass bottle of Coke). The service was very good throughout the entire dining experience and I was impressed that the servers came to change our grill often without us asking. The primary reason I am taking off a star from my review is that our server essentially bribed us into giving him a good review on Yelp by offering to comp our soft drinks. I assumed that meant we could write him a good review on our own terms, but instead he took our phones, copied and pasted an AI-generated review on Yelp, and asked us to post it. It was honestly quite uncomfortable and it makes me question how legitimate the other reviews are for this establishment. Just something to be aware of. Otherwise, I really enjoyed the meal and would recommend Niku X to other seafood and wagyu lovers. A must try experience - great quality meat and seafood!

Booked full service for 2 ($139pp) on a Thursday night. Arrived a few minutes late due to LA traffic - NikuX is located in the same building as the Intercontinental hotel in DTLA, on the second floor. Seated within 5 minutes in a nice window seat.

With the full-service menu, you get to order unlimited amounts of everything on the menu and some special items once.

Unlimited items: some items require preparation and you need to order the day before your reservation, such as the 45-day aged tomahawk - which we ordered. When we sat down, we immediately ordered Japanese A5 ribeye and tenderloin.

What we liked:
- Japanese A5 steaks - sliced thin, good quality, not a lot in each serving but because of the heavy fat content it fills you up quickly!
- Wagyu fried rice - whoever is working the wok on the rice is doing a great job!
- Unlimited lobster tails and king crab legs at the buffet - served chilled on ice, but supplied with lemons and butter and very fresh. And they‚Äôve cut the lobster tails in half to make it even easier to eat.
- Miso Sea bass - served in ‚Äúcubes‚Äù that were pan fried and served on a skewer. Very tasty

Not fans of:
- Shishito pepper

The special items (limited to one per person)
- Sashimi special - uni, toro, salmon, caviar - what‚Äôs not to like? Very tasty. Small portion but it was very good. I had both portions for the two of us that went‚Ä¶yum!
- King crab stuffed - served hot - very good
- Big head shrimp - served hot - also very good

Buffet - shrimp, other wagyu food options, like curry, fresh salad, vegetables, tempura - all unlimited and self-serve. Good selection.

Cocktails / wine - expansive menu - prices are about what you would expect for LA prices.

Service - Wissal was our server - very friendly - informative and professional. Thanks for a great time! In terms of the food service, honestly it was a bit slow. I know you get 2 hours to eat but we often sat 15-20 minutes with no steak despite ordering. That would probably be my only point of negative feedback. Quality was great. We left super full - but the long lag times to get cooked steak out on the full-service option was a bit disappointing. Next time, I might skip the full service and just get the self-service and cook my own meat over a Korean BBQ and take the wagyu they had at the buffet.

Now - if you make it to the end and you still have room for dessert - you can try it. Their tiny dessert station didn‚Äôt have anything great in my opinion. We tried a few things and were underwhelmed. But hey - we were already bursting at the seams from all the Wagyu :)

Niku X is not to be missed!
If you are looking for the highest quality dishes, a beautiful layout, or a secluded private room for a party or event -- this is the quintessential place to go. It‚Äôs like no other.

The moment you walk through their doors you are immediately greeted with a view of an immense kitchen, curated by Michelin Star Chef Shin Thompson. You can watch your meal being carefully prepared. It‚Äôs stunning.

Our fantastic waiter Chaeho did a phenomenal job presenting each elegant dish and conversing with us throughout our meal. We felt at home with his personal stories and interesting insights. Our superb assistant waitress, Phoebe, who helped bring out some of the dishes was very professional and sweet. The entire staff at this restaurant are top quality professionals.

Our first course, crudo, was very fresh and a perfect start to our meal. The astrea oscietra caviar, paired with senbei cracker and topped with gold leaf was astounding and a treat to the taste buds. I have never had such a beautiful visual as well as sensory moment. There was no heaviness, only pleasure with each bite. The black winter truffle was presented in a Louis Vuitton mini suitcase, and shaved onto the meat. Now I know what it feels like to be presented with an award!

The style and story behind each plate reflected the precision and passion of the kitchen. It‚Äôs obvious that the staff love what they do. I felt as though I was in an edible art gallery; the balance of texture and color was so artistic.

My favorite dish was the wagu platter, not just for the breathtaking display, but each cut of meat touched my tongue with intense flavor. To continue the journey, every course had a different palate cleanser with its own sensation.

The price is worth the entire experience. It is very special and one of a kind unique. I recommend it for an exceptional date night, or a gathering. I will never forget it. Service Dine in Meal type Dinner Price per person $100+

Negative.Context:
Over rated, over priced, and such a huge disappointing. This was supposed to be the highlight of our trip to LA. Instead it became the worst part of it.
We sat at a table without a grill - meaning our food was to be prepped by a chef and delivered to us instead of us cooking it ourselves (Korean bbq style). What I thought this meant was the food would be prepped to perfection and our service would be a lot better since the price difference was $50 per person. Instead we got cooked meat delivered to us cold, the slowest service I have ever seen at any restaurant, and pretty much the worst experience I have had in a very very long time. Every single time we ordered meat it came to our table cold. But because wagyu is so high in fat, the fat didn‚Äôt ‚Äúmelt in our mouth‚Äù it felt like we were chewing sticks of butter/lard. Dish after dish came this way. I was nearly about to lose my mind until we finally decided that we were both just done and ready to leave. That made me feel a lot better to just give up on the experience and decide to escape the place entirely.  The manager came by and asked if we were doing ok but it was only by the time we were about to ask for our check after the entire horrendous experience and leave. So he was too late. Nothing really happened after he heard about our experience. He said sorry and that he hoped he could make it right but we only had one more serving of meat left from our earlier order so there was really nothing he could have done except maybe make sure the last two tiny portions of meat don‚Äôt come out stone cold.
Their buffet food was very low quality, the service was super slow, and the price was really too high for what you get.
Anyways, I highly recommend skipping this place and I‚Äôm really not sure how they have such high ratings. They do seem to have a strong social media presence. Maybe that has something to do with it. Please just beware and don‚Äôt get disappointed like we did! Food: 1 Service: 1 Atmosphere: 4

This is a restaurant full of rules and quirks. You submit to the rules right on the reservation website, where you try to choose the menu you want to eat from, but the information is obscure and difficult to understand. Then, at the time of the meal, they try to put you on a more expensive menu, saying that it's for you... Enjoying the cheaper menu at $109.00 will require an extra hour's wait, and most customers are willing to pay the $158.00 menu, which is nothing special, just with fewer annoying rules for ordering dishes.
If you intend to eat wagyu beef, you can accept the higher price, but if you want seafood like King Crab and lobster, I don't recommend this place. They removed scallops and oysters from the menu, so it's not worth submitting to so many rules like time limits and restricted dishes, etc.
The King Crab is served cold, which makes it quite tasteless, while the Snow Crab is served hot and was very tasty.
It's nothing more than a restaurant with unfavorable cost-benefit!
Look for another place in Los Angeles that's like seafood, and you'll be much better served. Food: 2 Service: 2 Atmosphere: 2

Feeling + sweet and salty. There is no sign at the entrance on the first floor, so you have to ask the staff. Do not take the hotel elevator. Parking is only valet, and if you get validation, it costs $16.50 for 2 hours and 30 minutes. Wagyu BBQ is better than seafood. King crab. Lobster, sashimi. $109 (Friday, Saturday, Sunday). Make a reservation 2 months in advance. If you don't want to wait, you can eat at the bar for $139. For $109, I grill the meat. For $139, the staff grills it and brings it to you. Japanese A5 top sirloin flower. chelf choice A5. It's delicious, but it's too oily to eat a lot, so it's a shame. I thought From Chef would be special, so I ordered a few, but except for the lobster tail, there's nothing that's "wow~ delicious", and I'm so full that it's hard to eat anything else, so I don't recommend it. I think it felt even more greasy because there were no vegetables or refreshing flavors to go with the grill. I saw oysters and scrubs on YouTube, but they weren't there the day I went. The lobster was hard to eat because the shell didn't separate because they cooked it somehow. The king crab wasn't high quality, but it was all small and low quality and not very edible, so it was a bit disappointing. You have to call 24 hours in advance for dry-aged meat. The atmosphere is good, but the servers are busy and they bring it a bit late when you order. It's a bit disappointing because there's nothing worth eating for the price. I don't think I'll come back again because the price is too high. Food: 3 Service: 3 Atmosphere: 5

I headed they had been added to the Michelin guide, and I love Wagyu, so  I was excited to try their food. Unfortunately, the place was Beyond Overrated! We tried the 14-course menu, and some pieces were okay, but nothing was great. Their Wagyu A4 was their best piece (really good). Although, for an unusual reason, they added Blueberry sauce to their A5, which DESTROYED the meat's taste. It reminded me of a blueberry pancake. Such a waste of good meat.

The drinks were all right, and we liked them. Ambiance 3 stars (it wasn't bad, nothing unique. they had some artwork on a wall), service 1 star (empty glasses of water, multiple dishes on the table, I don't even want to start with napkins and everything else), Value 1 star (it would be acceptable for around $150-$200 not for $400). Overall, 2,3 stars for a high-end restaurant.

Btw if you are a vegetarian, don't get close to that place. They were dishonest about their offering (really disappointing). They charged the same price of $300ish ($400 with drinks/tip) for their veggie option (which wasn't even 5,6 courses compared to 14), and it was the worst veggie we had ever tried in any place in LA. We go to restaurants a lot. Most have been honest about their offering, for example, M√©lisse Restaurant, 2 Michelin stars; when I called them, they said they were sorry but couldn't accommodate Vegetarians, and I appreciated their honesty. They didn't try to rob us.

Should you go? If you have been to all high-end restaurants in LA, including Michelin restaurants (because that is what you are paying), and a lack of quality, service, and details doesn't bother you much, you can try this too.

I pay $400, sometimes even more, in many restaurants (including 3-star Michelin worldwide), and I am okay with spending that money for experience and greatness. Not because I have too much money to burn, which I don't. I had great experiences (and also some disappointing ones) throughout my journey. This restaurant was one of my worst experiences in any high-end restaurant (above the $250 range). Service Dine in Meal type Dinner Price per person $100+

Neutral.Context:
The wives planned birthday dinner for a total of 3 very hungry dads.  We went with the Tomahawk menu.

A few things in random order:

1.) Location is great and so is the decor.
2.) We were seated promptly (a Thursday).  Party of 6 but they don't really have any rectangular tables so we sat in 1 square and 1 circular table so we could all fit.  That was odd and annoying.
3.)  Service is slow.   The place was not busy but the server would disappear for awhile.  I know it's a buffet but restaurants make $$ on drinks moreso than anything else.
4.) The drinks were....meh.   I was looking for a fancy old fashion or mule.  Instead the drink menu had 6 or 7 l drinks and it seemed all pre-made and some slushy style with alcohol.  (Felt cheap) Not a fancy menu at all for the top dollar being spent.  The wine was good but came in a bottle (lol)
5.) Seafood options - Lobster, Tiger/large shrimp, sushi.  These options were good - however - I would go elsewhere and eat that as a separate meal.
6.) The Tomahawk was ok.   We ordered 1 per couple.  It was too much because that should've been a separate meal as well.  Instead of eating buffet/unlimited seafood and a big tomahawk.   It would've been better to eat twice there at a more modest price.  (That was our bad)
7.) The Tomahawk "show" to wow us.  Meh... maybe because I got older and it was a repeat of a past experience.  We had 3 Tomahawks and got 1 show.   We had to share the first Tomahawk because they didn't bring us the other 2 until 30 mins later.   Again restaurant was not busy at all.
8.) The bill.  The bill came and certain items that were comped because of the birthday were not.  They were charged. Also, when they fixed it they taxed us on the FULL amount vs the subtotal.  Their excuse was that the item was "prepared" so it's still taxable.  Lastly on the bill.  The tip was automatically included on again the full amount including the items comped.   So where they comped???  It all was corrected after their frustration.  Table was full of numbers people so.....yeah.  Saved $30 per person...worth it.

Overall, the spot is nice and the food ok for the price point and experience.

Go once and say you went.

If you go don't do the Tomahawk.  Get at the A5 if you can and balance that with the seafood.

Some folks question the legitimacy of the wagyu quality.   I'm not a connoisseur but will say that I'll stick to my ribeye and the smaller cuts of Wagyu. Food: 3 Service: 2 Atmosphere: 4

Hubster and I visited for our 27th wedding anniversary and we were BLOWN AWAY!  Perfect service (they actually carried in a bench seat for us because the chairs were too narrow) all the food was amazing! But I highly suggest the Chilean Sea Bass wraps! Life changing!!! The sashimi was THE best I've had in SoCal.  We loved that they had warm butter on tap (I would have preferred it to not be garlic butter) The steaks absolutely ruined me for all future steaks! Melt in your mouth doesn't do it justice.  I expected to focus on the lobster tail but to be honest, I was a little disappointed in them. I tried 3 different tails and none of them were easy to remove from the shell even though they were all cut down the back. The flavor was good however and they were nice sized. The star of the night was by far the Chilean Sea Bass!!! Do not skip it! We paid $119 each plus $16 for valet parking (loved that option) and we considered it completely worth every penny. Even if its only a once in a lifetime visit, you should definitely go! Let‚Äôs talk about Niku X‚Äîbecause at around $150 per person, you expect an extravagant experience. What I found was something just shy of that.

Ambiance & Service (4.5/5): The restaurant sits a few floors up, and our dinner with another couple started off smoothly‚Äîwe were seated immediately with a reservation at a window table overlooking the street. The layout is thoughtfully arranged with enough space for movement and wheelchair access. It can host everything from small parties to large groups (we saw a table of ~20). The ambiance is upscale, modern, and lively, though the bathrooms felt underwhelming‚Äîsmall, limited stalls, and the trash was overflowing.
Service overall was attentive. Our waiter was friendly, offered great recommendations, and staff were quick to help when we accidentally spilled a drink‚Äîcleaning it up professionally and replacing it without question. Plenty of servers and even managers circulate the floor to assist. At this price point, I would have expected the premium cuts to be cooked table-side by staff rather than us, but that‚Äôs more of a missed opportunity than a dealbreaker.

Food: The wagyu was solid‚Äîhard to get wrong, and I‚Äôd give it a 4.5/5 so long as cuts aren‚Äôt too thick or thin. Seafood, however, was mixed. The carpaccio was fresh and flavorful, but the king crab legs were small, dry, and more effort than reward. Bibs would have been a thoughtful touch given the mess factor. The snow crab legs, on the other hand, were the highlight of the night‚Äîwe kept going back for more. Still, the overall spread left me wanting more variety, particularly in veggies, fruit, and dessert. At this price, I‚Äôd expect at least a fruit bar and a stronger dessert selection.

Overall: Niku X delivers a refined dining experience with polished service and a strong ambiance, but at $150 a head, I expected a bit more across the board‚Äîespecially on seafood variety and premium touches like tableside grilling. Worth a visit for the snow crab legs and the wagyu, but not quite the fully extravagant experience I anticipated. A5 Wagyu Heaven ‚Äî Worth Every Penny

The $149 all-you-can-eat A5 Wagyu beef experience at Niku is absolutely worth it. This isn‚Äôt just dinner‚Äîit‚Äôs a culinary event. The cheaper tier lets you cook the meat yourself, but I wouldn‚Äôt recommend that‚Äîespecially if you‚Äôre like me and don‚Äôt even enjoy cooking at home. Ruining such delicate, premium beef would feel like a crime.

There‚Äôs a wide range of offerings beyond beef‚Äîseafood, sushi, sashimi, caviar, lobster, and more. But trust me:

Come hungry.
Start with the A5 Wagyu beef‚Äîdon‚Äôt get distracted by other dishes too early.
Stick firmly to your preferred doneness, even if the waiter suggests otherwise.
After trying at least two A5 Wagyu cuts, then go all out on everything else.

Their miso soup is rich and comforting, and the other beef cuts are also delicious. The desserts, though? Honestly, underwhelming‚Äîbland and forgettable.

Service has been consistently excellent on all my visits. Book well in advance‚Äîthis is a rare dining experience. They claim to be the only one of its kind in the country, and I believe it‚ÄîI haven‚Äôt seen anything like this elsewhere. For a whole restaurant chain known to focus on Japanese Waygu, Niku X is supposed to be one of their flagships. To that end they deliver on the vibe and experience, but the food is rougher.

Overall the buffet is high quality, but the Waygu options, at least on the regular buffet menu, are decidedly meh - they have other Chubby Group restaurant brands that do a better job for the money. If you go for the higher end menu the experience is likely better but then you‚Äôre even more of a premium. Combined with the fact that reservations are so hard to get and I am decidedly meh.

Final note, service is indeed excellent, and Joe, our server, was terrific. Wow, what a stunning, high class experience. Nate, our server, was one of the best parts of the experience, checking in on us regularly and explaining the process slowly and clearly without making us feel silly. He really made us so comfortable with such a new experience, and I really hope he gets his accolades for it!

The food itself is amazing. The buffet felt underwhelming after we finished the tomahawk wagyu experience but everything from the chef in the all-you-can-eat was just spectacular. Even without the buffet, the all-you-can-eat plus the tomahawk for three people was more than enough.

The atmosphere is nice, very dim in the restaurant with a small lamp at your table. Might be hard to see for those with vision impairments. The music didn't really match the atmosphere in my opinion, I think I'd prefer a calmer playlist rather than an indie pop-adjacent playlist. It also was a smidgen too loud for me.
