Your restaurant is an embarrassment of an establishment. You ruined my birthday, a party of 12, by losing aka ‚Äúnever receiving‚Äù my reservation. I made the reservation a week and a half before. We spoke twice over the phone about the menu, how I would receive a call 24 hours before the reservation, menu options, how I would need to choose a specific menu so that we could be sat cohesively together, my number, email‚Ä¶ there is no excuse. My friend wrote a review on how poorly handled the conversation went hours before our arrival when we called to see what was going on. You told him you would follow up, even made us send you evidence of our calls which is really quite embarrassing not only on treatment on our part as a special occasion, but also on the lack of professionalism on your part on what is supposed to be a fine dining establishment. It is clear you are nothing of a sort as you never even contacted me and I am here to let the charade you put on that you take care of your customers post terrible experiences is false. You ruined my birthday, and now you are ruining your own reputation. I will be contacting the Better Business Bureau as well as the local media for how terribly this was handled. I‚Äôm extremely disappointed with the experience I had with this restaurant‚Äôs reservation system and management. We made a reservation two weeks ago, and the staff confirmed it multiple times, they took down our name, phone number, and email, and assured us that our reservation was confirmed.

When we called today to reconfirm, we were told that there was no record of our reservation. To make matters worse, the manager we spoke with was very unhelpful and unwilling to provide any appropriate support or solution.

This level of disorganization and lack of customer care is unacceptable for a restaurant of this caliber. We had planned our evening around this reservation and were left extremely disappointed. I hope management takes this feedback seriously and improves both their reservation system and customer service going forward. Service: 1

‚≠ê‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ Extremely Disappointed ‚Äì Special Celebration Ruined

We made a reservation at Niku X weeks in advance for a party of 12 to celebrate a dear friend‚Äôs birthday. On the day of the event, the restaurant claimed they had no record of our reservation. This was incredibly upsetting, especially since this was meant to be a special night.

To make matters worse, the manager was very unprofessional and rude when we tried to resolve the issue. Instead of helping us or showing any empathy, they dismissed our concerns entirely. We had to scramble last minute to find another place for our group, which completely ruined the celebration.

I would not recommend Niku X to anyone planning an important occasion. A restaurant of this caliber should know how to manage reservations and treat guests with respect.

The Asian male server with short hair was unbelievably rude and unprofessional. He completely ignored us, even when we called him multiple times, because he was too busy fawning over a large party.

I came here with my girlfriend for our anniversary a few days ago, and while there were some nice moments, our overall experience was very disappointing.

We had a reservation and arrived about ten minutes late, but the staff was kind enough to seat us right away and were very accommodating at first. Unfortunately, the restaurant seemed pretty understaffed that night, which made it difficult to get our waiter‚Äôs attention when we needed anything.

The main attraction here is supposed to be the high-quality meats, but honestly, most of what we were served tasted very similar, and none of it came close to the quality you‚Äôd get at a high-end steakhouse like Baltaire. For a restaurant charging $150 per person, the experience just didn‚Äôt justify the price. The buffet was also limited and felt underwhelming.

The biggest issue, though, came afterward. The shrimp we tried tasted off, and a few hours later both of us became violently ill, with nonstop vomiting and painful stomach issues that lasted through the night. When we called the restaurant to let them know, the only response we received was, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry that happened.‚Äù There was no effort to follow up, investigate, or offer any form of assistance or compensation. This is a restaurant full of rules and quirks. You submit to the rules right on the reservation website, where you try to choose the menu you want to eat from, but the information is obscure and difficult to understand. Then, at the time of the meal, they try to put you on a more expensive menu, saying that it's for you... Enjoying the cheaper menu at $109.00 will require an extra hour's wait, and most customers are willing to pay the $158.00 menu, which is nothing special, just with fewer annoying rules for ordering dishes.
If you intend to eat wagyu beef, you can accept the higher price, but if you want seafood like King Crab and lobster, I don't recommend this place. They removed scallops and oysters from the menu, so it's not worth submitting to so many rules like time limits and restricted dishes, etc.
The King Crab is served cold, which makes it quite tasteless, while the Snow Crab is served hot and was very tasty.
It's nothing more than a restaurant with unfavorable cost-benefit!
Look for another place in Los Angeles that's like seafood, and you'll be much better served. Food: 2 Service: 2 Atmosphere: 2

This restaurant was a major disappointment. I cannot believe that my parents and I spent $500 only to receive such poor service. On multiple occasions, I had to get up from the table because our server was nowhere to be found. We repeatedly asked for the table to be cleared, yet it remained cluttered throughout the meal. To make matters worse, the desserts were brought out while the table was still in the same state, as shown in the attached photo‚Äîfurther reflecting the lack of attention to service.

I chose the highest-tier buffet option, which is advertised as including premium Japanese beef cuts. However, the seafood selection was extremely underwhelming. The so-called King Crab was completely tasteless and appeared to have been frozen for a long time. As shown in the photos, the crab legs were unusually thin and lacked any substantial meat, making it clear that they had been stored frozen for an extended period. The same applies to the entire seafood bar.

Regarding the Japanese beef cuts, I have been to Japan over ten times and dined at no fewer than six reputable steak houses. Based on my experience, the beef served here was clearly frozen, and its quality was mediocre at best. While the restaurant claims to offer A5-grade meat, I find that highly unlikely. I have had A5 beef on numerous occasions, and while these cuts may indeed be Japanese, they do not meet the standards of true A5 quality.

The service was equally disappointing. Beyond the lack of attentiveness, the dessert‚Äîa simple H√§agen-Dazs ice cream‚Äîwas served in its original packaging with plastic spoons, showing a complete disregard for presentation. This level of service and quality might be acceptable at a $30-per-person establishment, but certainly not at a restaurant charging over $150 per person.

I hope this review helps others make an informed decision and avoid an experience that falls far short of expectations. Service Dine in Meal type Dinner Price per person $100+ Food: 1 Service: 1 Atmosphere: 1

Dined at this place, and the disappointments just keep rearing its ugly head. The reservation and the menu are misleading at best, downright scammy at worst.

Welcome to bait and switch at its finest.

First of all, nowhere in the reservation process tells you that if you reserve $139/$149, you will NOT have a grill. So that's the biggest surprise. When asked, the server was trained to ask back, "Did you reserve a grill?" Knowing in the reservation process, there was no indication of reserving a grill or table service. You would think that important detail should be indicated.
Not sure why their reservation system was set up this way, regardless if it's the poor planning and designing or if it's intentionally done, we felt tricked.

Second, the menu you see on their official website is a joke. You'd think the menu online is updated and is what you'll get and is what you used to decide if you'll dine here, Surprise! Most of the items we wanted are not on the "restaurant menu". For example, Oysters, grilled or raw, were nowhere to be found, and there were absolutely no scallops. The ultimate sashimi platter disappeared from the menu as well. And guess what, all the waygu meats that you see on the menu and it's at the buffet station that you thought was unlimited? Yeah, NOPE, you can't grab them because you ain't got a grill üòÇ. Jokes on you. You have to order them, and they take 30+ minutes to arrive at your table cold with no flavor. Just imagine undercooked fatty meat cold and bland in your mouth. ü§Æ

Finally, the food. Like I mentioned, the sliced waygu meats were gross. They were undercooked, cold, and tasteless. The Tomahawk Steak was good. It needed more black pepper and salt but was cooked perfectly. Handful selections of raw food at the buffet station were good. It's probably the only thing I enjoyed. Lobster tails were ok, but the crab legs sucked. The small dishes "from chef" sucked real bad. The dessert was disgusting.

NO, it's definitely not worth the price.

**Disappointing Experience at Niku X**

We had high hopes for our visit to Niku X, but unfortunately, the experience fell far short of expectations. As a group of eight, we booked the full-service option and arrived at 8:30 PM for our 8:45 reservation. Despite arriving early, we weren‚Äôt seated until 9 PM, which was frustrating and set the tone for the evening.

Once seated, things only got worse. The grill at our table was broken, and we were told there was no other table available to accommodate us. Since we paid for the full-service option, we weren‚Äôt even allowed to grill our own meat, which we would have preferred given the circumstances.

The service was painfully slow. It took over an hour for the first round of our limited 15 items to arrive, leaving us with little time to enjoy the meal within the 2-hour limit. The presentation of the meat was subpar‚Äîcuts were not well-prepared or what you'd expect from a high-end restaurant.

The most disappointing part was the quality of the food. The A5 wagyu beef from our second order was chewy and lacked the signature tenderness you‚Äôd expect from wagyu. It was so poor that we questioned whether it was even wagyu at all.

While some staff members were polite, the overall experience was not worth the $1,500 we paid. Waiting for food, dealing with a broken grill, and being unable to enjoy the meal as promised made for a truly disappointing evening. We won‚Äôt be returning and can‚Äôt recommend this restaurant. I hate being a party pooper, especially when I am a huge fan of Chubby group restaurants like Mikiya and X Pot. But tonight, we were completely underwhelmed by Niku X. This restaurant  most definitely underdelivered for the $139 that they were charging. As a family, we eat fresh seafood regularly. So, we know what freshness tastes like. Perhaps it was the Thanksgiving long weekend and their suppliers had hard time delivering fresh seafood, or perhaps the restaurant's latest delivery was the day before Thanksgiving, when we visited the restaurant on Saturday, the seafood simply tasted unfresh. Many fish dishes had a mushy/slimy texture to them, and the shrimps/lobsters tasted unusually plain. The A5 Wagyu beef was tender, but they were all served on a large cold plate. By the time they were delivered to our table, the Wagyu pieces were all lukewarm. And eating beef with high fat content at a lukewarm temperature was definitely not an enjoyment, and even the Wagyu fried rice was lukewarm when served. The manager did come out and apologize, which was a nice gesture. I might try this restaurant again in the future, but will definitely avoid long weekend at all cost. BTW, I tried to scan the receipt using their Chubby app to accumulate points in the parking garage, but the app said it could only scan while we were physically inside the restaurant. So, for those of you who wish to use their app to accumulate points, please make sure to do so before you leave their premises.

Update: I had to down grade their food from 2 stars to 1 because both my older son and I had a miserable night last night after we came home. Food: 1 Service: 4 Atmosphere: 4

If I can rate this place as 0/5 I would. I was utterly appalled and frankly disappointed in this establishment. If you want cheaper AYCE wagyu/sushi, I think driving to one of their sister restaurants is more cost efficient (such as Yumiyaki, Mikiya, or even Chubby Cattle). Those other restaurants are cheaper and judging by how they serve sushi and Japanese Wagyu also, it's better to get those dishes there than pay a butt load for this place.

We got the upgraded option of $139, and opted out to order any large steaks that you pre- order (ex. tomahawks range from 35-40 oz, and some other options that you can select of your choosing.

Service: Extremely horrendous. I had runners/staff members not even know the simple aspect of having certain condiments at their restaurant. One runner said they didn't have tabasco, but had chili oil; only for a FOH manager to come by and say they have no tabasco and chili oil. Our server kept getting our orders wrong which caused a delay in our meat being served because we were sat at a non-grill table. Our server admitted to getting the orders wrong completely. Wait was over 15-20 minutes long in between waiting for the next round. Runners/servers also kept serving dishes on the side of the table even if there was room in the middle of the table. Dishes were not cleaned up. I had almost 4 plates stacked just from appetizers because I was starving between rounds of meat never coming essentially.

Ambiance: The restaurant is nice, but with the amount of complaining tables surrounding our area, I definitely didn't think that I was at a high end semi fancy restaurant at all. Interior is dark and nice, but the buffet line could use some work as it is a narrow walkway and some patrons decide to stand and block the way as well.

Food: Subpar at best. If I wanted to get expensive cut meat and be paying for 139 for it, I should be getting top quality. It was lukewarm at minimum every time we received the meat. It wasn't cooked to our medium rare liking, and some of the meats weren't the ones we ordered since our server got out order wrong multiple times.

Manager Education: Its pretty comical when even the managers of this establishment aren't well trained, couldn't answer simple questions of why the wait was taking so long, why the service was horrible, and why the raw seafood bar was completely barren for a great portion of the time. When we asked these questions, they completely invalidated our party and didn't try to resolve the solution or provide alternatives in any way possible. Pretty disappointing for a restaurant group that I've had pretty adequate experiences at their other sister restaurants.

Overall, I am not stepping into this establishment again. This wasn't even half of the entire experience. I saw an influencer table get up and not touch their food or pay at all, and then another couple order the tomahawk and have a few bites and left, and then the table that got seated after they left also got up and complained why the food was delayed and the service was pretty unbearable. I advise eating at their sister restaurants for much cheaper like chubby cattle, yumiyaki, or even mikiya. At least you'll pay for the service you're getting and the quality of food. One of the worst experiences ever and to top it off, I sent an email to their feedback group and they promised they would get back in 48 hours, and they never got back to me :(. Save your money, and your wrinkles on this place. Service Dine in Meal type Dinner Price per person $100+ Food: 1 Service: 1 Atmosphere: 1

The food was terrible, and each dish took at least 15 minutes to prepare. At 139 yuan, this buffet is absolutely not worth the price. The service was also awful. They gave us a tiny table, and after we finished eating, no one came to clear our plates; we had to call them multiple times before they came. If you want to order drinks, remember, they are extra, and the staff won't tell you! The only difference between the 99 and 139 yuan buffets is that you can only order one of four dishes per person, and each serving only contains two pieces of food. Almost all the seafood was very stale; the only decent thing was the cake. We had to find a server three times and waited over ten minutes to pay the bill. A truly awful experience! Honest Experience at Niku X in LA (900 Wilshire)
First time 9/28/24

I had high hopes for Niku X, but the overall experience was quite disappointing. First off, much of the food was served cold and lacked flavor. The dipping sauces were sparse, and the tomahawk steak, which we expected to be a showstopper, was not only small for a table of six but also had burnt ends.

The crab legs were served cold as well, and the garlic butter tasted like it had no garlic in it at all. Even the hot meats were completely unseasoned, which was a huge letdown. This is far from what I‚Äôd expect from a restaurant claiming Michelin star-level quality.

Another issue was the table itself‚Äîit was far too small for the number of people and dishes. Plates and cups were constantly bumping into each other, which made the meal feel cramped and uncomfortable. For a fine dining experience, you‚Äôd think the space would be better suited for the number of dishes they serve.

On the positive side, our waitress Wissal was wonderful, and her service was top-notch. No complaints there. However, I was annoyed to find that we were charged for water without being informed in advance. I don‚Äôt mind paying, but a heads-up would‚Äôve been nice.

The drinks were strong, but at the price point they charge, you'd expect nothing less. In the end, Niku X did not live up to the Michelin star standards they claim to meet. For the cost, the experience left a lot to be desired.

STAY AWAY!! RUN, DON‚ÄôT WALK!!

We visited on 8/31 for the AYCE tasting menu for $99 and it was a big disappointment in all aspects.

To start off we had a reservation on OpenTable for 7:30PM and we arrived at 7:25PM only to wait an additional hour until we were sat.

The AYCE selection was mostly absent, the walk up bar for food was empty most of the night. Only American wagyu options were available in the fridge, no Japanese wagyu AT ALL. Crudo station was empty with exception of a few small dishes being set out occasionally that would go quickly. NO KING CRAB was ever available on any of our visits to the buffet line.

While eating, my wife bit into a small plastic bead pictured below which appears to be a hair bead that was somehow fallen into the food she ate. Absolutely disgusting!!!

As for the service, it was also atrocious!! Once we were sat, we ordered waters for the table and a kids cup for my son. My wife and I received our water but our son‚Äôs never came so we asked again. Wait 20min, still no water so we ask again. We wait again no one comes to the table to check on us or asks if we need anything until 20min later when a bus boy comes around and asks and we finally got the water for my son 40minutes after we got ours. After this, I walked to the host stand to speak to the manager about how we were upset about the food/water situation and was told that a manager would be sent over but guess what? No manager ever showed. We then asked for our check through the bus boy and waited roughly 15min before asking again because no one ever brought it. A manager was finally brought our check and we made him aware of the situation. Manager was very apologetic and offered to comp one of our meals.

I would never visit this establishment again nor would I ever recommend it.

Disappointing Experience and Dangerous Mix-Up

This is the first time in my life I felt the need to write a bad review

We visited NIKU X for dinner and were deeply disappointed by the service. Despite their last call being at 10 PM, we arrived at 9:50 PM and were promptly informed that food orders needed to be placed before 10 PM. We quickly placed our order at 9:55 PM.

However, when we ordered our drinks, the bartender's attitude was less than welcoming. My partner, who is allergic to alcohol, ordered a non-alcoholic drink, while I ordered an alcoholic one. The bartender clearly did not want to make our drinks as they were preparing to close.

When our drinks were served, my partner's non-alcoholic drink contained alcohol. This could have been disastrous if we hadn't realized in time, especially considering my partner's allergy. Fortunately, we lived upstairs, but had she been the designated driver, this mistake could have put us in a very difficult situation.

After waiting for half an hour, the manager approached us to inform us that due to a miscommunication, the kitchen was unable to prepare our food. He offered to pay for our drinks and said he would see what leftovers were available in the kitchen to serve us. Offering leftovers after making us wait for half an hour is simply unacceptable. We were extremely hungry after being out all day, and they could have informed us much sooner so we could have found somewhere else to eat.

Overall, this experience was incredibly disappointing and potentially dangerous due to the mix-up with the drinks. We hope the management addresses these serious issues to prevent future incidents. Service Dine in Meal type Dinner Food: 1 Service: 1 Atmosphere: 2

Today was the first time in a while where I realized I am ONLY an Asian living in LA.

From the moment me and my visiting friend sat down at the table, the waitress handed over menus with some sass.

Two of us ordered, one appetizer, four entrees, and two drinks, which came out to be $402.

Starting with the appetizer, food came out one at a time. One of the dishes we ordered was sashimi platter. After putting the dish on the table, explaining the platter, the waiter from the kitchen, accidentally touched/ poked the food. He tried to laugh off by saying ‚Äúahahahahh,‚Ä¶ oh my gosh~~ I‚Äôm so sorryyyy~.‚Äù Then he walked away. It‚Äôs a lawsuit. The fact that he touched a raw fish then walked away laughing without even offering to bring out a fresh new plate was the first red flag.

And to continue with the sashimi, it was the worst sashimi I had in my life. Not only was it not fresh, the color, texture, the way it was sliced‚Ä¶ the food was done at a level that could have been done by a teenager at home.

Then when entrees started coming out, the waitress came over to move around plates on the table to make some space. As she was doing so, she spilled a bowl of soy sauce on the table and into my wasabi bowl. The sauce nearly missed my white jacket. When I asked the waitress to wipe the soy sauce, she said she will get it wiped without even an apology.

Lastly the $180 kobe striploin was such a waste of money. 40% was fat, not even from marbling, but just excessive fat that should have been taken care of in the kitchen.

Out of five dishes we ordered, we only finished one, which was wagyu tartare. Wagyu fried rice, we didn‚Äôt even attempt to taste it as it looked like a microwaved frozen beef rice.

At last the manager came over to ask what was unsatisfying about the meal. When I told him everything including some other details not included in this review, he took the two plates of sashimi and the wagyu fried rice out from the check.

Simultaneously he gave me his business card saying the next time I make a visit he will provide special course menu + explained how some of their sashimis are dry aged, causing them to not ‚Äúlook‚Äù fresh. Listen, this isn‚Äôt my first day on this planet eating dry aged sashimi. The fact that the manager tried to cover up the whole unsettling experience with his story of dry aged sashimi shows he himself doesn‚Äôt have the basics down as for a manager.

It is very hard to believe that this restaurant is even on the Michelin guide. Service Dine in Meal type Dinner Price per person $100+ Food: 2 Service: 2 Atmosphere: 3 Recommended dishes

do you know how bad a place has to be in order for someone who has never submitted a review to feel compelled to write one up mere minutes after eating? you would think being on the michelin guide meant something. i have never felt more robbed by a restaurant.

let me try to paint a picture. we arrive for an 8PM reservation only to wait 20 minutes to be seated in a nowhere near full restaurant. i watch later parties be seated by the same staff that has walked by me multiple times. i have to ask the hostess if anyone planned to seat me, to her surprise.

at this point, you see the rolling robots that bring drinks and dishes to tables. it‚Äôs the kind of thing that feels cute in a small sushi joint, but feels tone-deaf in a giant upscale restaurant with tons of staff that is marketing a five-star experience.

i attempt to order sake to pair with this meal. no luck. this alleged high-end japanese wagyu joint is somehow out of nearly every sake on the list. the beverage director has to come to our table to recommend a bottle - as if they or i had a choice.

we came for the a la carte menu but decided to try the ‚Äúpremium‚Äù tasting menu thinking it‚Äôd be worth the price. we couldn‚Äôt have been more wrong.

for starters, why am i able to smell the bluefish tuna ‚Äúcrudu‚Äù (server‚Äôs words, not mine) and why does it taste fishy? the scallop was somehow cooked enough to develop a inedible outside layer. the caviar and potage are good but that in and of itself is very hard to mess up. there is no brine to the caviar and the popcorn added to the potage is gimmicky. amateur hour at a restaurant of this purported level.

you‚Äôll learn that the staff is instructed to tell you where everything is from - australian this, african that. so much so that the kimchi persian cucumber is somehow from japan. you think you came to experience japanese barbecue only to be served banchan and pregrilled vegetables slathered in sauce.

we go through 3 rounds of grilled meat and every single one of them is tough, chewy, and flavorless. it is the last 3 meats they serve where you think ‚Äúfinally‚Äù‚Ä¶ this is what you came for. the server will tell you to pick from your choice of ribeye, striploin, or kobe as your final course. he‚Äôll fail to mention that the kobe is an extra charge added to your already extremely overpriced meal.

we asked for chocolate cake and cheesecake for the dessert, but instead we got lavender cake. in our server‚Äôs words ‚Äúthis is on us.‚Äù what generosity! can someone explain how that is possible on a pre fixe meal?

i have to laugh at this entire experience to keep from feeling completely taken for a fool. absolutely nothing about this place is premium. save yourself the time and money by dining elsewhere. anywhere in sawtelle or koreatown runs laps around this overhyped and overpriced restaurant. when multiple servers pronounce wagyu as ‚Äúwa-goo‚Äù, run. I recently went to NIKU X Los Angeles, which is on the 2nd floor of the Intercontinental Hotel.

The place has a beautiful ambience‚Äîclean, classy, and perfect for a nice night out.
They offer valet parking and validate for 2.5 hours, but since we had three cars, we still ended up paying almost $100 extra after the free hours. For just over an hour of staying‚Äîdining, picture-taking, and exploring the hotel‚Äîit felt a bit pricey just for parking.

When it comes to the food, they have two options: $109 per person and $149 per person.

The $109 already includes unlimited lobster, seafood, beef, sushi, sashimi, and more from the buffet.
The $149 option is marketed as the ‚Äúpremium experience,‚Äù with unlimited Japanese A5 Wagyu and a few other special dishes.

We decided to go for the $149 option for the experience.
The unlimited Wagyu sounds great, but to be honest, it was underwhelming.
If you‚Äôve had authentic Japanese A5 Wagyu before, you‚Äôd know the taste and quality are usually outstanding even without seasoning.
But here, it just didn‚Äôt have that same melt-in-your-mouth flavor.

For me, it felt overpriced and not really worth the hype.
Meanwhile, the ‚Äúspecial seafood‚Äù at $149‚Äîlike king crab legs, shrimp with caviar, and a few other items‚Äîare only served once, not unlimited.

The best part of the evening was actually the ambience and the service.
Our server Naomi was amazing‚Äîfriendly, attentive, and she explained everything so clearly.
She really made my birthday celebration special.

Overall, if you‚Äôre a seafood lover, I‚Äôd say just go with the $109 option.
You already get plenty‚Äîlobster, shrimp, sushi, sashimi, and more‚Äîwithout spending extra on Wagyu that doesn‚Äôt really stand out.

The $149 feels too expensive for what it offers. The place is definitely beautiful, the service is excellent, but next time I‚Äôd probably just stick with the $109‚Äîor maybe try another spot.

If you‚Äôve had authentic Japanese A5 Wagyu before, you‚Äôd know the taste and quality are usually outstanding even without seasoning.
But here, it just didn‚Äôt have that same melt-in-your-mouth flavor.

For me, it felt overpriced and not really worth the hype.
Meanwhile, the ‚Äúspecial seafood‚Äù at $149‚Äîlike king crab legs, shrimp with caviar, and a few other items‚Äîare only served once, not unlimited.

The best part of the evening was actually the ambience and the service.
Our server Naomi was amazing‚Äîfriendly, attentive, and she explained everything so clearly.
She really made my birthday celebration special.

Overall, if you‚Äôre a seafood lover, I‚Äôd say just go with the $109 option.
You already get plenty‚Äîlobster, shrimp, sushi, sashimi, and more‚Äîwithout spending extra on Wagyu that doesn‚Äôt really stand out.

The $149 feels too expensive for what it offers. The place is definitely beautiful, the service is excellent, but next time I‚Äôd probably just stick with the $109‚Äîor maybe try another spot.

From seeing all the reviews and recommendations from YouTube, I have to say, the whole experience was somewhat a letdown, given the cost to dine here.

The entire setup of the restaurant is definitely not suitable for a get up and grab your own food style buffet and the selection to grab is also very limited. It was honestly a weird experience since the menu itself is actually pretty standard in size, but the presentation and idea to get up to grab the food from the serving area was awkward.

You would have to wait for a refresh of new food to grab, and given that the restaurant had a decent size, felt somewhat awkward when there wasn't any food left, or very few left to grab.

Some of the appetizers were pretty good, but others were really surprisingly lackluster. The ceviche that is always offered has a very bland flavor, it felt like it was missing some core flavor profiles.

For the price of $100+ before tax and tip, I honestly felt like I could've went anywhere else for this price and had a more positive memorable meal. We visited NIKU X for a special Mother‚Äôs Day lunch with my mom and my mom‚Äôs boyfriend‚Äôs daughter-in-law. While the restaurant definitely looks upscale and visually impressive, the experience unfortunately didn‚Äôt live up to expectations.

Service was a major letdown. It felt like we were lucky just to get our waiter‚Äôs attention during the entire meal. For a place that presents itself as fine dining, the level of attention and hospitality was severely lacking.

As for the food, the meats were just okay‚Äînothing special or memorable. The buffet selection was very limited, especially considering the high price point. What‚Äôs worse is that the lunch menu doesn‚Äôt offer the variety or quality you‚Äôd expect compared to dinner, yet it‚Äôs still expensive.

For what we paid, I expected top-tier meats and exceptional service. Instead, we left feeling disappointed and like the whole experience was overpriced for what little was offered. I wouldn‚Äôt recommend coming here for lunch, especially if you‚Äôre expecting the kind of selection and service that should come with a premium price tag. First of all, the food is good and fresh but the dining experience will be good ONLY IF you reserve the right menu option. We had the $159/person menu Without Grill on table  although the menu we got as well as the web clearly says $149/person( kind of misleading). First round we tried the JP A5 Ribeyes and Striploin which both melts in your mouth with an aroma that is indeed A grade JP Wagyu beef. We also grab some crab legs from the station and crab meat is warm and fresh. Everything seems to be good for the first 30 minutes and then things went south. It took them 30 minutes to get the 2nd round of the Wagyu steak from the kitchen AFTER we complained to the waiter for wait 20 minutes for nothing. Although the waiter and the manager did manage to get the steak speed up later on, even offering free drinks, we ended up with lots of Wagyu steaks on the table at the same time and it soon became too overwhelming while eating too much oily steak for such a short period of time. Till the end, we realized that we never even get the lobster tail we ordered earlier while they will never forget your appetizers. As for the dessert, they have a limited selection of cake flavors. Make sure you order the ones you like in between the dining otherwise you might not be able to get the flavor you want at the end. Overall, crab labs are good, shrimp is okay,  sashimi is average but at least they all taste fresh. A5 Wagyu only the Premium 5 oz Wagyu Worth the try but not the special Wagyu cut. If you like seafood, just go with the basic menu option. If you want Wagyu, make sure you reserve the table WITH GRILL or you will get GRILLED. By the way, for the owner, you need to update your website about the pricing otherwise it is misleading for the table with or without a grill. I'll admit that I currently have food coma from overeating, but I am still a bit disappointed from the experience. The joint is basically just a bougie buffet.

The place has ambiance. Decor and staff make you feel like it's an elevated dining experience. But I came here to stuff my face for 2 hours, not admire the lighting.

To make it simple, I'll just rate what I ate as a list. I don't feel like typing paragraphs of pulp. We both got better things to do.

All the A5 wagyu:
Wow, melt in your mouth beefy goodness. After this, anything leaner will just be leather. Make sure you don't grill it too long. Rare to medium is the way to go for this stuff.

All the other beef:
It's okay. But bad. If you want to try it, do it before the A5.

Beef tataki:
Yummy. Had three rounds of it. But that's if you like rare/raw beef. The sauce/marinade is what made it delicious. Refreshing, but I'm sure a more accurate descriptor could be used.

Lobster:
Not bad, but kind of boring in it's own. Luckily they have plenty of things to dip it in. If you don't like it cold, throw it in the grill for a few minutes.

King crab:
Huge disappointment. SO SALTY. I know they do this so you don't eat a mountain of it, but this is a bit extreme. The first round of four pieces is all we ate. It's as salty as the typical snow crab at your local cheap Chinese buffet. NIKUX, I guess you've accomplished your mission since we ate only one round.

Snow crab:
Didn't touch after eating the king crab. I would be flabbergasted if it was actually less salty. But I doubt it.

Selection of raw fish:
Tuna is okay. Yellowtail could be better. Didn't try the poke though.

Oysters:
Wow, you gotta love oysters to consume these. So fishy and "oyster" tasting. Yeah, yeah, I'm an oyster amateur. Or maybe it's old?

Scallops:
Fresh and sweet. Complete opposite to the oysters. Not fishy at all.

There are many items you order through server and they bring from the kitchen. Didn't get to try all of them, but the sea bass was tasty. The sando was yummy also, but you don't want to fill up of that stuff. Didn't do any of the rice dishes since it wasn't cooked with enough water when we ate the yakisuki at the beginning of the meal.

Desserts:
Whatever. The chocolate mousse thingy was the best out of the selection.

One thing that I really didn't like is that when you're done with dinner and you've paid your bill, the server will ask you to leave them a review by scanning a QR code. But the server will click on the options in your phone to give themselves a review and submit it before you even know what's going on. A bit shady.

Is it worth $99? Yes, because of the real A5 and the lobster. But other than that, nothing there makes want to go back and have it again. Been there, done that, move on. Service Dine in Meal type Dinner Price per person $100+ Food: 3 Service: 4 Atmosphere: 4
